title: Norovirus Is Ripping Through Hockey Teams at the 2026 Winter Olympics, Causing Scheduling Issues
description: Team Finland's women's hockey team had a number of players come down the virus, and Team Switzerland had one, prompting a game postponement on Thursday, Feb. 5 and another possible one on Saturday, Feb. 7.
content:
Team Finland and Team Switzerland have had players affected by norovirus
The Olympic Village is all fun and games ‚Äî until someone catches the highly contagious norovirus.
The notorious stomach virus has been slowly making its way through a few women‚Äôs hockey teams, prompting delays and postponements at the 2026 Winter Olympics in Milan.
On Feb. 5, the Games announced that the women‚Äôs Finland versus Canada ice hockey game would be postponed after Team Finland experienced a norovirus breakout.
‚ÄúThe decision was taken following consultations with medical professionals after cases of norovirus were identified within Team Finland,‚Äù the Games said in a press release. ‚ÄúIt was made collectively and in accordance with established health and safety principles, with the health and wellbeing of players, team staff, officials and all tournament participants as the highest priority.‚Äù
The release acknowledged the ‚Äúdisappointment‚Äù of the postponement, but said it was a ‚Äúresponsible and necessary decision that reflects the spirit of the Olympic Games and the integrity of the competition.‚Äù
Thirteen members of Team Finland were either infected with the virus or in quarantine, the Associated Press reported. General manager Kimmo Oikarinen told the outlet on Feb. 6 that while the illnesses were ‚Äúdisappointing,‚Äù things were ‚Äúgetting better for the team."
‚ÄúForfeit is the last thing we want to do. I don‚Äôt believe we will go there. I do not see that happening,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt is the Olympic Games, and we have been waiting for this for years. We all wanted to play, but there are things that happen. The main focus was to make sure our players will be healthy as soon as possible.‚Äù
Norovirus is a contagious virus that causes vomiting and diarrhea, per the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. While most people with the illness get better within one to three days, they can still spread the virus for a few days after.
Meanwhile, the Swiss Hockey Federation announced on Feb. 6 that one of its female hockey players had also tested positive for norovirus, shortly after Team Switzerland beat the Czech Republic in a hockey game.
The organization‚Äôs statement said the infected athlete had been housed in a single room since she arrived at the Olympic Village on Monday, Feb. 2, and was isolated from the team after she started exhibiting symptoms.¬†
Though the athlete was symptom-free as of Feb. 6, the team was isolated after the match, and the women‚Äôs Swiss national hockey team did not take part in the opening ceremony.
The Swiss Hockey Federation said on Saturday, Feb. 7 that the team will go ahead with their game against Canada as planned, because no one else has exhibited symptoms.
"The incubation period has now passed. Thanks to the immediate response and the prompt isolation of the affected player and the team, the potential chain of infection was broken early on,‚Äù said Hanspeter Betscharat, chief medical officer for the Swiss Olympic team. "From a medical perspective, there are currently no concerns about the match taking place, provided no further players show symptoms.‚Äù

Team Finland and Team Switzerland have had players affected by norovirus

title: Everything Cardi B Has Said About Her Plastic Surgery, from Removing Her Butt Injections to Getting a Boob Job at 18
description: Cardi B has received cosmetic procedures ranging from a rhinoplasty to liposuction. Here‚Äôs everything Cardi B has said about getting plastic surgery.
content:
Cardi B has always spoken candidly about her experiences under the knife
Mireya Acierto/Getty ; Cardi B/Instagram
Cardi B is an open book when it comes to the work she‚Äôs had done.
The ‚ÄúBodak Yellow‚Äù rapper has undergone several elective surgeries since she shot to fame in 2017, and she‚Äôs never shied away from discussing her experiences under the knife with her fans.
Cardi has also been candid about the motivation behind her cosmetic work, which has more to do with her personal preferences than with self-esteem.
‚ÄúPeople will be assuming that when you do surgery, you‚Äôre insecure about yourself or you hate yourself, and that‚Äôs just not the truth,‚Äù she explained during a November 2024 appearance on The Jason Lee podcast. ‚ÄúIf I want to correct something or do a little something something, I‚Äôm going to do it.‚Äù
‚ÄúI like being perfect,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúI like a certain type of body for myself.‚Äù
From her breast augmentation to the procedures she‚Äôs regretted, here‚Äôs everything Cardi B has said about plastic surgery.
Long before she became famous, Cardi used money she earned working as a stripper to pay for a breast augmentation. During a 2021 conversation with Mariah Carey for Interview Magazine, the rapper shared that she had been insecure about her breasts since she was young.
‚ÄúI was really skinny when I was younger, and in the Bronx, it‚Äôs about being thick and having an ass, so young boys would be like, ‚ÄòLook at your flat ass. You ain‚Äôt got no titties,' " she recalled. "And it would make me feel so ugly and undeveloped."
She continued, ‚ÄúWhen I was 18 and became a dancer, I had enough money to afford to buy boobs, so every insecurity that I felt about my breasts was gone.‚Äù
Soon after getting her breasts done, Cardi moved on to her butt, and at age 21, she got biopolymer injections, silicone-based fillers that are not approved by the FDA and can cause life-threatening complications. The procedure cost the rapper $800 and was performed in a basement in Queens, N.Y.
‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt numb your ass with anything,‚Äù she told GQ in 2018 of the risky procedure. ‚ÄúIt was the craziest pain ever. I felt like I was gonna pass out. I felt a little dizzy. And it leaks for, like, five days.‚Äù
Years later, in August 2022, Cardi had ‚Äú95%‚Äù of her biopolymers removed. She opened up about the process during an Instagram Live that December and offered her fans some advice about plastic surgery.
‚ÄúAll I'm going to say is that if you're young, if you're 19, 20, 21, and sometimes you're too skinny, and you be like 'OMG I don't have enough fat to put in my ass,' so you result to ass shots, DON'T!‚Äù she said.
Cardi continued, ‚ÄúWhen it comes to BBLs, if y'all want advice from me, before you get your BBL done you have to make sure your blood levels are all right. If a doctor says your blood levels are too low or you have diabetes or whatever, don't do it."
In January 2024, Cardi got another round of injections removed.
Shortly after her debut on Love & Hip Hop: New York, Cardi treated herself to a smile makeover with celebrity cosmetic dentist Dr. Catrise Austin. She had several porcelain veneers placed, and the experience was featured in the first episode of season 7 of the reality show.
‚ÄúIt was just something that people kept talking about ‚Ä¶ and I knew I was going to do more on TV,‚Äù she told a reporter at the season 7 premiere in November 2016. ‚ÄúI don't want my teeth distracting people from my talents or what I do.‚Äù
The rapper was so happy with her new smile that she included the line ‚ÄúGot a bag and fixed my teeth‚Äù in her breakout hit, ‚ÄúBodak Yellow.‚Äù
During her appearance on The Jason Lee podcast, Cardi opened up about how she never liked her nose and always wanted it to be smaller.
"I always felt like I had a big nose," she explained. "Even before I was famous, I was like 'Damn, I've got my daddy's nose.' ... I was always afraid to do my nose and I finally took that step."
In 2019, she opted for nose fillers, as several people told her it was a better, non-surgical way to make her nose smaller. However, the fillers had the opposite effect.
‚ÄúThat s--- f---ed my nose up,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI was like, 'Oh my Gosh, what the f--- did I do to myself?' "
‚ÄúWhen you see stuff on Instagram, it makes sense. But fillers made my nose longer ... it got wider," she added.
Cardi then went through with a rhinoplasty in 2020.
While performing at the Beale Street Musical Festival in May 2019, Cardi revealed that she had recently undergone liposuction.
‚ÄúI have some news for y‚Äôall. I should have canceled today,‚Äù she told her fans. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt really be performing because moving too much is gonna f--- up my lipo. But b---- I‚Äôm still gonna get my motherf---ing money back, let‚Äôs go!‚Äù
A few weeks later, Cardi had to postpone several scheduled performances after being given ‚Äústrict doctor‚Äôs orders‚Äù to take it easy after her surgery, her rep told PEOPLE.
Cardi first floated the idea of liposuction in August 2018, one month after she welcomed her daughter, Kulture Kiari, whom she shares with ex-husband Offset.
‚ÄúI still feel like I got a lot of love handles right here,‚Äù she said during an Instagram Live. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not much but it‚Äôs like ‚Äî I‚Äôm used to having, like, a real tight stomach.‚Äù
Years later, while appearing on Alex Cooper‚Äôs Call Her Daddy podcast in September 2025, the ‚ÄúWAP‚Äù¬†rapper addressed a misconception that she is ‚Äúalways [on] the table‚Äù and explained that she didn‚Äôt get liposuction or any other procedure immediately after she gave birth.
‚ÄúI take my time because I don‚Äôt want to die,‚Äù she explained. ‚ÄúYou have to wait six, seven months before you get any type of surgery after you give birth because you lose so much blood. Your body is still contracting. Your organs are still contracting. Your breasts are getting smaller.‚Äù
In the same interview, Cardi opened up about whether she regrets any of the procedures she‚Äôs had.
‚ÄúI look at myself in the mirror and it's like, I really wouldn‚Äôt change a thing,‚Äù she told Cooper. ‚ÄúMaybe I would like my butt to be smaller ‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs, like I said, really hard for my butt to get smaller. I already did a reduction.‚Äù
She went on to describe how painful and lengthy the reduction process is, adding about her critics, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not going to put myself in that position again because you don‚Äôt like my body.‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôm comfortable; I learned to live with it. I don‚Äôt get no complaints from nobody,‚Äù she concluded.
Cardi added that she feels she can't "win" the public, who she said will critique celebrities for hiding what procedures they've had done, but equally criticize her for being open.
‚ÄúIt really sucks so much,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhen you do tell them your business, it‚Äôs bad too ‚Ä¶ you can never win.‚Äù

title: PEOPLE's Editorial Policy
description: PEOPLE, one of the world's most-read digital publications, fights against viral misinformation by having steadfast journalistic standards
content:
If you read it on PEOPLE, you know it is true. In a world of rumors run wild, there are all kinds of stories that take the internet by storm and provoke strong reactions ‚Äî even from major public figures ‚Äî before anybody even knows if the information is true. As one of the world's most-read digital publications, we take seriously our responsibility to fight against viral misinformation by having steadfast journalistic standards that guide us in telling true, accurate, and authoritative stories ‚Äî always.
Every piece of content on PEOPLE is conceived of, created, and communicated to you with these core principles front of mind.
Bringing you the latest news is a big, never-ending production. Our reporters are among the most connected people in the world: on the red carpet, at the White House, in the worlds of tech, sports, style and beauty, food and more.
But we also shine at finding those small, never-before-heard stories of ordinary people doing extraordinary things‚Äîin any zip code in this country and beyond. Our news team members have their fingers on the pulse and keep you plugged in to what's happening, minute by minute, no matter the hour of day, and continuously as the story unfolds. And our expert editors are there to give you the best recommendations: what to watch, read, listen to, wear, cook and buy.
At PEOPLE, we hold some principles sacred. We will not publish a photograph of a celebrity's child taken against their parents' wishes, barring a serious news value. We believe in a person's right to privacy, so we will not expose a pregnancy or someone's health issues against their wishes, nor will we share identifying details that might betray the location of the home where a public figure resides. We always strive to have an open dialogue with the people we cover and give them an opportunity to tell their stories.

You may notice PEOPLE covers some pretty heavy topics, from themes of drug abuse and sexual assault to child abuse or suicide. At every turn, we're committed to helping you gain insight from these incredibly personal stories or be inspired to help: we will help you find a story subject's GoFundMe, if you're moved to make a donation, or we'll give you helpful resources if you or someone in your life is in a similar situation.
We have stringent guidelines for writing about suicide, and work in partnership with #CrisisTextLine to encourage people to make the call for help if they're struggling with their mental health. And we vet and will share links to legitimate 501c3 charities when we cover major developing news about everything from environmental crises to the war in Ukraine.

At its core, PEOPLE is a brand devoted to highlighting diverse stories: The triumphs, tragedies and extraordinary moments in the lives of all people. We have always been committed to representing as many voices as possible and work constantly to seek out and showcase new ones. We seek always to improve the diversity and scope of the talent we profile, stories we cover, people we feature, and platforms we amplify. It is a top priority for PEOPLE to be transparent about the steps we're taking to ensure our content is representative, fair, educational, and inclusive.
At PEOPLE, we strive to be a safe, inclusive, and judgment-free place to consume content. We apply rigorous standards to the language we use around sexual orientation, gender orientation, race, mental and physical health, including body issues and how people become families. PEOPLE is also guided by the People Inc. Anti-Bias Review Board, which advises on our content to ensure that it is free of bias and as inclusive as possible.
Accurate information is at the core of every story we publish at PEOPLE. Our writers and editors investigate rumors and claims and verify all information gathered for all we publish. We consult credible, in-the-know sources to ensure we're providing proper context and background. Our work is rigorously evaluated for accuracy, relevance, and timeliness during the editing process.
But if you ever find fault with a story we've published, or have a substantive update or possible correction to share, we want to hear from you. Please email corrections@people.com.
We are committed to telling you if a factual error has been made on a news story at the time of publication. We will correct the error as quickly as possible and append a clearly-labeled note to inform you of the corrected information. When an article is factually correct, but the language is not as clear or detailed as necessary, the story may be updated without an editor's note.
Our editorial teams do their best to update our large library of "evergreen" stories to ensure they continue to be timely, accurate, and relevant. Each article is date-stamped to reflect when they were last updated.

In the age of COVID and vaccine misinformation, no topic requires expert precision and more intense fact-checking than health coverage. To that end, our health team relies on the PEOPLE Health Squad, a team of doctors with specialties in many different areas we have at the ready, to explain and put into context everything from the latest recommendations on booster shots to that episode of And Just Like That that covered perimenopausal menstruation. We told you we take this stuff seriously.

Our writers and editors adhere to strict sourcing standards in all our articles. All facts and claims are backed up by at least one reputable source, and we aim to be transparent as to the origin of information in any developing situation.
In our crime coverage, or in the case of a major disaster, where first responders and law enforcement respond to the scene, we rely on the district's Public Information Officer, interviews directly with members of law enforcement and court documents for the facts of the case. We always make every effort to reach out to legal representation for all defendants, or any individuals that are profiled in our coverage.
PEOPLE journalists often receive information from trustworthy confidential sources whose names are withheld from publication. We want you to understand that these sources are not "anonymous" but are known to the PEOPLE team. They are granted confidentiality for publication purposes and the information they provide is verified with other sources. When we grant confidentiality to sources, we aim to provide context to our readers about the reasons they are not named.
At PEOPLE, we never pay for stories or tips, as we believe it can compromise the integrity of our journalism. Likewise, we do not accept monetary compensation in exchange for coverage of products. Our writers and editors are prohibited from giving preferential treatment to any outside resource (company, publication, video, affiliate, website) based on their relationship with the person or company who authors or owns that resource. Each staff member and contributor is held to a high standard of honesty and transparency.
Our goal at PEOPLE is to provide original, unbiased, credible content. We expect all contributors on the network to abide by all applicable laws, standards, and accepted journalistic practices, including:
Part of our mission at PEOPLE is to provide you with thorough, unbiased shopping information. We cover everything from the latest celebrity trends, the best sales, as well as our PEOPLE Tested program which covers everything from skincare to kitchen gadgets. In our PEOPLE Tested program, we do the heavy lifting by running products through vigorous testing at one of our three testing labs throughout the country.
Here, we test products against a comprehensive methodology that rates products on various attributes (think performance, durability, ease of use, etc.). No product makes it into our Pet Awards, Beauty Awards, or Food Awards packages without rigorous testing by a panel of editors and experts. Our goal is to provide you with as much information as possible before you decide to buy something. These product recommendations are purely editorial, and we may receive a commission on any purchases that you make.
Learn more about our testing methodology here.

title: Cardi B
description: Cardi B is a rapper and reality TV star. The Bronx native first gained attention on Instagram before joining the cast of VH1's reality TV series 'Love & Hip-Hop: New York' in 2015. She released her debut single "Bodak Yellow" in 2017, earning two Grammy nominations. In 2019, she won her first Grammy for best rap album.

title: Mariah Carey
description: Mariah Carey is a Grammy-winning American singer, songwriter, and actress. Since the success of her 1990 self-titled album, Carey has become one of the best-selling musicians of all time. With 19 number-one singles, Carey has more than any other solo artist. She was inducted into the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 2020.

title: Cardi B Reveals Her Butt Injections Leaked for 5 Days: 'It Was the Craziest Pain Ever'
description: Cardi B opens up about the body enhancement she received four years ago
content:
The rapper tells GQ about getting scary plastic surgery in a basement four years ago
There‚Äôs very little Cardi B hasn‚Äôt shared about herself, whether it‚Äôs anecdotes from her former career as a stripper or insight on how she‚Äôs grappling with the pressures of instant fame. But her latest revelation might be her most personal yet.
In a new interview with GQ, the rapper, who confirmed rumors of her pregnancy during an SNL performance over the weekend, revealed that four years ago she had shady butt injection plastic surgery done in a basement in Queens.
The star said she received an underground, $800 butt-enhancing treatment at the age of 21 because she wanted to make more money as a stripper. But because she ‚Äúdidn‚Äôt have enough meat‚Äù on her body, she couldn‚Äôt go for liposuction to transfer fat to her backside. So instead, she had a woman inject fillers into the area.
‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt numb your ass with anything,‚Äù she told GQ of the dangerous plastic surgery procedure. ‚ÄúIt was the craziest pain ever. I felt like I was gonna pass out. I felt a little dizzy. And it leaks for, like, five days.‚Äù
https://www.instagram.com/p/BfUnrG2hsxE/?hl=en&taken-by=iamcardib
It seems that Cardi was one of the lucky ones, because when she went back for a second round of injections, the woman who administered them was allegedly in jail.
RELATED PHOTOS: Stars Who Love Their Plastic Surgery
‚ÄúBut by the time I was gonna go get it, the lady got locked up ‚Äôcause she‚Äôs supposedly killed somebody. Well, somebody died on her table.‚Äù
RELATED PHOTOS: All the Fabulous Ways Cardi B Hid Her Baby Bump This Year
The star, who feels empowered showing some skin on stage and social media, revealed a personal body transformation on Saturday, flaunting her baby bump during a performance on Saturday Night Live.
‚ÄúThe love I‚Äôm receiving is overwhelmingüò©!‚Äù she wrote in response to her supporters. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt thank you enough for always finding the time to share your support!! Thank you a million times @badgalriri.‚Äù

title: Cardi B Shares Advice for Anyone Considering Plastic Surgery After Removing Her Butt Injections
description: The rapper warned her fans to do research and listen to doctors before getting any cosmetic procedures
content:
The rapper warned her fans to do research and listen to doctors before getting any cosmetic procedures
Cardi B is giving an update on her experience with plastic surgery.
The "Up" rapper, 30, recently appeared on Instagram Live and warned her followers about doing their research before getting cosmetic procedures done. She explained that she wanted to be open with her fans because "a lot of people thought as soon as I gave birth [to son Wave, 15 months] I got my body done."
"In August I got surgery and I removed 95% of my biopolymers... if you don't know what it is, it's ass shots. It was a really crazy process," Cardi B ‚Äî who previously discussed getting the illegal silicone shots for $800 in a basement in 2014 ‚Äî explained. "All I'm going to say is that if you're young, if you're 19, 20, 21, and sometimes you're too skinny, and you be like 'OMG I don't have enough fat to put in my ass,' so you result to ass shots, DON'T!"
"When it comes to BBLs, if y'all want advice from me, before you get your BBL done you have to make sure your blood levels are all right," she added. "If a doctor says your blood levels are too low or you have diabetes or whatever, don't do it."
Cardi B, who also confirmed her recent rhinoplasty, has never shied away from discussing her plastic surgery experiences. Back in 2021, she said the enhancements make her feel confident.
"Well, I'm from New York, right? And New York is a melting pot, especially where I grew up in the Bronx. I was really skinny when I was younger, and in the Bronx, it's about being thick and having an ass so young boys would be like, 'Look at your flat ass. You ain't got no titties.' And it would make me feel so ugly and undeveloped," the rapper said in an intimate conversation with Mariah Carey for her Interview cover story.
When Cardi was old enough to work as a dancer in a strip club, she used her earnings to get breast implants, which was the first step toward forgetting about her insecurities.
"When I was 18 and became a dancer, I had enough money to afford to buy boobs, so every insecurity that I felt about my breasts was gone," she said at the time. But by age 20, enhancing her butt became her next priority. "When I was 20, I went to the urban strip club, and in the urban strip clubs, you had to have a big butt. So I felt insecure about that. It took me back to high school. So I got my ass done."
In addition to her previous augmentations, the rapper underwent a second breast surgery as well as liposuction in 2019 following the birth of daughter Kulture, now 4.

title: Cardi B Reveals She Got Another Round of Butt Injections Removed in January
description: Rapper Cardi B revealed during a recent Instagram Live that she got another round of butt injections removed in January 2024.
content:
The mom of three began the process in 2022
Cardi B¬†is giving fans an update on her butt injection removal process.
In a recent Instagram Live, the rapper, 31, who welcomed a daughter earlier in September, announced that she had more of her butt injections removed earlier in the year.
"In January, right after I shot 'Like What,' I went and got surgery. I got some more butt injections removed. Because, you know, it takes rounds to get your butt injections removed. I got some of my butt injections removed. And I also went to fix, like, you know, certain things [with] my fibrosis," said Cardi.
Pierrick Rocher/BFA.com/Shutterstock¬†
The Grammy winner previously revealed during a December 2022 Instagram Live that she had "95%" of her biopolymers removed from her buttocks that August. Biopolymers are silicone shots that Cardi previously told GQ she got for $800 in a basement in 2014.
The PEOPLE Puzzler crossword is here! How quickly can you solve it? Play now!
In 2017, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration¬†issued a safety communication warning consumers that "injectable silicone used for body contouring is not FDA-approved and can cause serious side effects that may be permanent or may even lead to death."
"Side effects can include ongoing pain and serious injuries, such as scarring, tissue death, and permanent disfigurement; if the silicone migrates beyond the injection site, it could cause an embolism (blockage of a blood vessel), stroke, infections and death. Serious complications may occur right away or could develop weeks, months, or years later," added the federal agency.
Later in the Instagram Live, Cardi also shared how she "automatically" knew she was pregnant again when she "woke up one morning and my mouth tasted like copper."
In addition to their newborn, Cardi and Offset share daughter¬†Kulture Kiari, 6, son¬†Wave Set, 3.
The mom of three¬†has been candid about her postpartum journey on Instagram, giving fans a view of her stair master workouts and new mindset.

Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for¬†PEOPLE's free daily newsletter¬†to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer‚Äã‚Äã, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.
"This is my third baby and postpartum is a little different from my first two... I'm not doing heaving lifting, no muscle straining, squatting none of that... just cardio," she previously wrote on X. "Sometimes to avoid postpartum depression you gotta keep your mind busy and for me that's work and staying active..."

title: Cardi B Says Kim Kardashian Gave Her Plastic Surgery Advice After Botched Nose Fillers
description: Cardi B revealed she had "no choice" but to get a nose job after getting bad fillers done in 2019
content:
Cardi B revealed she had ‚Äúno choice‚Äù but to get a nose job after getting bad fillers done in 2019
Cardi B has never shied away from discussing her plastic surgery experiences, and now the rapper is detailing her unwanted nose job after receiving botched fillers.
The 30-year-old appeared on a new episode of REVOLT's The Jason Lee Show where she opened up her past cosmetic procedures and how Kim Kardashian gave her surgeon recommendations for a nose job.
"I always felt like I had a big nose," Cardi told host Jason Lee. "Even before I was famous, I was like 'Damn, I've got my daddy's nose.' I was always afraid to do my nose but I finally took that step."
The "WAP" rapper recalled being told by several people back in 2018 that nose fillers were a better and non-surgical way to make her nose smaller, so she went through with it.
"I did fillers on my nose in 2019. And that s‚Äî f‚Äî--- my nose up," she said before admitting that she didn't even know how the fillers were supposed to work. "I was like, 'Oh my God, what did I do to myself?'"
Cardi said it's important for her to share her horror story for those who are considering similar procedures.
"When you see stuff on Instagram, it just makes sense. But fillers just made my nose longer and it got wider," Cardi explained, adding that because of the botched procedure she had "no choice" but to get surgery on her nose.
Lee then asked the Grammy winner how she decides which doctors perform her surgeries, recalling a moment when Kardashian, 42, gave her some advice.
"I remember the time we were at Kris' [Jenner] house and Kim gave you a list of people you could call to get help," he said. "You didn't call none of those people?"
"No, I called a couple of people that she gave me," Cardi responded, noting that she ultimately went with someone else and got her rhinoplasty in 2020.
Now, Cardi said she's done with plastic surgery, boasting, "I look great." During the podcast, she also assured that there's nothing wrong with her decision to get any cosmetic procedures.
"This is the tricky thing about a lot of people. People will assume when you do surgery or something, you're insecure about yourself or you hate yourself, and that's just not the truth," Cardi said. "If I want to correct something, if I want to do a little something-something like ‚Ä¶ I'm gonna do it. I like being perfect. I like a certain type of body, like, for myself."

title: Cardi B Confirms She Got Liposuction: 'I Shouldn't Really Be Performing'
description: The rapper told the crowd at the Beale Street Music Festival that she's not supposed to be "moving too much"
content:
The rapper told the crowd at the Beale Street Music Festival that she's not supposed to be "moving too much"
Cardi B is owning up to getting liposuction.
After denying it for months, the 26-year-old rapper told the crowd at the Beale Street Music Festival in Memphis on Sunday night that she did get the plastic surgery.
A few songs into her set, Cardi B, dressed in a skin-tight, sparkly red jumpsuit, said that she shouldn‚Äôt really be on stage.
‚ÄúI have some news for y‚Äôall. I should have canceled today,‚Äù she said at the festival, sponsored by Facebook. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt really be performing because moving too much is gonna f‚Äî up my lipo. But bitch I‚Äôm still gonna get my motherf‚Äîing money back, let‚Äôs go!‚Äù
The crowd erupted into laughs and cheers after her announcement.
Back in August, one month after giving birth to her first child, daughter Kulture Kiari, Cardi B floated the idea of getting liposuction.
‚ÄúI still feel like I got a lot of love handles right here,‚Äù she said, while pulling on her tummy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not much but it‚Äôs like ‚Äî I‚Äôm used to having, like, a real tight stomach ‚Ä¶ I might just get a little lipo, you know what I‚Äôm sayin‚Äô?‚Äù
RELATED VIDEO: Cardi B Says She Did Not Get Liposuction After Giving Birth ‚Äî and Shows Off Her Abs
Two months later, in October, the ‚ÄúI Like It‚Äù singer showed off her toned stomach on her Instagram story, but said it was all natural.
‚ÄúI never did lipo, bro. Never,‚Äù she told the camera.
However, last Wednesday she revealed that she had a second breast augmentation.
‚ÄúI just got my boobs redone,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI feel good, but then sometimes I feel like not, you know? [When] your skin is stretched out. Yes, my daughter f‚Äîed me up. She did. She so did.‚Äù
A day later, Cardi B wowed fans with her rock-hard abs at the Billboard Music Awards. Decked out in an ab-baring, two-piece yellow outfit, she went on to win six awards.
Cardi B will attend the annual Met Gala on Monday night in New York City ‚Äî this year the event has a camp theme.

Cardi B is owning up to getting liposuction.
After denying it for months, the 26-year-old rapper told the crowd at the Beale Street Music Fes...

title: Cardi B Postpones Several Concerts to 'Fully Recover' from Plastic Surgery Procedures
description: "Cardi was overzealous in getting back to work, she didn't take the time necessary to full recover from her surgery," her rep tells PEOPLE
content:
"Cardi was overzealous in getting back to work, she didn't take the time necessary to full recover from her surgery," her rep tells PEOPLE
Sarah Michaud is the senior news editor of PEOPLE's music vertical. She has been working at PEOPLE for 18 years.
Cardi B has postponed several upcoming concerts after being given ‚Äústrict doctor‚Äôs orders‚Äù to take it easy following her recent plastic surgery procedures.
A rep for the 26-year-old rapper tells PEOPLE, ‚ÄúCardi was overzealous in getting back to work; she didn‚Äôt take the time necessary to fully recover from her surgery.‚Äù
‚ÄúHer strenuous schedule has taken a toll on her body and she has been given strict doctor‚Äôs orders to pull out of the rest of her performances in May,‚Äù the rep adds.
On Monday, many fans expressed concern on Twitter after reports surfaced that Cardi had backed out of a Memorial Day Weekend concert in Maryland. The Grammy Award-winning rapper was set to headline the 92Q Spring Bling Festival Friday night.
The radio station later confirmed the news, explaining the show would be postponed to a later date as a result of health issues.
Cardi was also scheduled to perform Tuesday night at El Paso County Coliseum in Texas.
‚ÄúShe‚Äôs very disappointed as she hates to let her fans down,‚Äù Cardi‚Äôs rep says. ‚ÄúShe reassures them that she will see them in September.‚Äù
After denying having had the procedure last fall, Cardi admitted at the Beale Street Musical Festival in Memphis on May 5 that she had recently undergone liposuction.
A few songs into her set, Cardi, dressed in a skin-tight, sparkly red jumpsuit, said that she shouldn‚Äôt be on stage.
‚ÄúI have some news for y‚Äôall. I should have canceled today,‚Äù she said at the festival, sponsored by Facebook. ‚ÄúI shouldn‚Äôt really be performing because moving too much is gonna f‚Äî up my lipo. But bitch, I‚Äôm still gonna get my motherf‚Äîing money back, let‚Äôs go!‚Äù
Cardi later said she changed her mind because she wanted to tell the truth.
‚ÄúIt was important for me because I don‚Äôt like lying about things,‚Äù she told E! News on May 8 during a performance for her new Fashion Nova collection.
Cardi said she also wants people to understand that liposuction results don‚Äôt happen immediately.
‚ÄúLike when you see somebody that had lipo, you think that they just go into the doctor‚Äôs and like boop, you come out and you look amazing, and it‚Äôs actually like a very long process, recovery,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt actually takes like a little bit more than three or four months.‚Äù
‚ÄúThe stages are very frustrating,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúSometimes it gets a little bit discouraging. You have to get your massages all the time. And sometimes, it might not come out like you wanted it to be. But right now, I‚Äôm actually enjoying it.‚Äù
One issue she does have, though, is when people doubt that her ab muscles are real.
‚ÄúWhat I don‚Äôt like is people who are like, ‚ÄòShe did ab sketching.‚Äô And it‚Äôs like, no no no,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI always had abs, and I‚Äôm a very skinny person so when they‚Äôre taking extra fat out and your skin is tightening more, like my bones actually show more.‚Äù
Back in August, one month after giving birth to her first child, daughter Kulture Kiari with husband Offset, Cardi floated the idea of getting liposuction.
‚ÄúI still feel like I got a lot of love handles right here,‚Äù she said, while pulling on her tummy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not much, but it‚Äôs like ‚Äî I‚Äôm used to having, like, a real tight stomach ‚Ä¶ I might just get a little lipo, you know what I‚Äôm sayin‚Äô?‚Äù
Two months later, in October, the ‚ÄúI Like It‚Äù rapper showed off her toned stomach on her Instagram Stories, but said it was all natural.
‚ÄúI never did lipo, bro. Never,‚Äù she told the camera.
On May 1, she revealed that she had recently had a second breast augmentation.
‚ÄúI just got my boobs redone,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI feel good, but then sometimes I feel like not, you know? [When] your skin is stretched out. Yes, my daughter f‚Äîed me up. She did. She so did.‚Äù
A day later, Cardi wowed fans with her rock-hard abs at the Billboard Music Awards. Decked out in an ab-baring, two-piece yellow outfit, she went on to win six awards.

title: New Mom Cardi B Wants Liposuction to Get Rid of Her Post-Baby 'Love Handles'
description: Cardi B shared on Instagram that she's not happy with the "love handles" on her post-baby body and wants liposuction
content:
Cardi B shared on Instagram that she's not happy with the "love handles" on her post-baby body and wants liposuction
Adjusting to your new body after having a baby can be challenging, and new mom Cardi B is speaking out about this struggle ‚Äî and considering taking matters into her own hands.
The 25-year-old rapper welcomed her first child, a baby girl named Kulture Kiari, with husband Offset on July 10. And just seven weeks later, she said in an Instagram Live video that she‚Äôs considering liposuction to remove some of the extra pounds and loose skin around her stomach.
‚ÄúI still feel like I got a lot of love handles right here,‚Äù she said to the camera on Thursday as she pulled on her tummy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not much but it‚Äôs like ‚Äî I‚Äôm used to having, like, a real tight stomach.‚Äù
The Bodak Yellow hitmaker also shared that she doesn‚Äôt have time to work out ‚Äî ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm not working, I gotta make sure my baby‚Äôs okay,‚Äù she said ‚Äî so she‚Äôs exploring a surgical option. ‚ÄúI might just get a little lipo, you know what I‚Äôm sayin‚Äô?‚Äù she told fans.
Want all the latest pregnancy and birth announcements, plus celebrity mom blogs? Click here to get those and more in the PEOPLE Parents newsletter.
But is liposuction a good idea only seven weeks after giving birth?
According to Mary Jane Minkin, MD, a practicing gynecologist and professor at Yale School of Medicine, the answer is no ‚Äî largely because it just wouldn‚Äôt be effective. ‚ÄúOf course I would never encourage this!‚Äù she tells PEOPLE.
During pregnancy, a woman‚Äôs body gains weight ‚Äúdiffusely‚Äù so it‚Äôs all over the body, Dr. Minkin says, whereas liposuction targets weight in one specific part and it‚Äôs impractical to do it everywhere. What‚Äôs more, the stretched skin lots of moms have after pregnancy will not ‚Äúdisappear‚Äù with liposuction.
RELATED VIDEO: Cardi B Says She Hasn‚Äôt Gotten a Nanny for Daughter Kulture: I ‚ÄúWant to Learn How to Be a Mom‚Äù
‚ÄúYou can suck out some fat cells, but the skin will still be looser,‚Äù she explains. ‚ÄúAnd liposuction won‚Äôt tighten your muscles. Exercise will.‚Äù
She adds, ‚ÄúA fabulous way to lose weight after a baby is breastfeeding. You will feed the baby 500 calories or so a day initially. Then, as the baby grows, you will be feeding her up to 1,000 calories a day.‚Äù
Cardi B and Offset, 26, seem in awe of their baby girl. Just last week, the Grammy-nominated artist shared a sweet photo of herself and the Migos member looking down sweetly at their little one.
Although most of the baby‚Äôs face was cropped out, the proud mom did show the top of Kulture‚Äôs head and a tiny white bonnet. ‚ÄúKultureK,‚Äù she captioned the Instagram post.
Since giving birth in July, Cardi B has managed to keep Kulture out of the spotlight. However, she has shared a few glimpses with her fans.
On Friday, she posted a video of the back of Kulture‚Äôs head with a hand gently touching her, writing on her Instagram Story, ‚ÄúI love my grandpa.‚Äù
Earlier this month, the new mom posted an Instagram Story of her baby girl‚Äôs cute feet. ‚ÄúI got home at 8:30 a.m. from my flight she been up this whole time! I fed her twice and bath[e] her she ain‚Äôt with it,‚Äù Cardi B wrote over the black-and‚Äôwhite photo.

Adjusting to your new body after having a baby can be challenging, and new mom Cardi B is speaking out about this struggle ‚Äî and cons...

title: Cardi B Shares Scenes from Kulture's 7th Birthday Celebration on Private Plane as Offset Calls Daughter His 'Inspiration'
description: Cardi B and Offset are celebrating their little girl. On Thursday, July 10, Offset shared a touching tribute for his and the "I Like It" rapper's daughter Kulture's 7th birthday on his Instagram. The proud mom posted some special moments with her daughter on a private jet.
content:
The rappers welcomed their daughter in July 2018
Offset/Instagram; Santiago Felipe/Getty¬†
Cardi B and Offset are celebrating their little girl.
On Thursday, July 10, the Migos rapper, 33, shared a touching tribute for his and the "I Like It" rapper's daughter Kulture's 7th birthday on his Instagram. In the post, the proud dad included several pictures and videos throughout the years of his little girl, including one with him feeding her as a baby and another of her making snow angels during the winter.
"Kulture Kiari‚Ä¶. Happy birthday my angel from heaven‚Ä¶. my super star‚Ä¶ my inspiration‚Ä¶ daddy loves you and i am thankful for your beautiful pure soul‚Ä¶ you are truly a blessing!!!" he wrote in the caption. "Time has gone so fast‚Ä¶. BIG 7 I can‚Äôt believe it already!!!!!!!!"
Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer‚Äã‚Äã, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.¬†¬†
Cardi B also shared a sneak peek of her daughter's birthday festivities via Instagram Stories.
In one of the clips, the 7-year-old can be seen enjoying some time with her friends while doing the whip and nae nae dance. The next video showed the birthday girl opening up some of her presents on a private jet.
The famed rapper is a father to six children. He shares three children with fellow rapper Cardi B: their¬†daughter Blossom, 10 months, son¬†Wave Set, 3,¬†and¬†Kulture. He also is a father to sons Kody, 10, and Jordan, 15, and daughter Kalea Marie, 9, from previous relationships.
When he spoke with PEOPLE in honor of his new collaboration with Doritos in September 2022, the "Ric Flair Drip" rapper opened up about¬†balancing his career with being a father.
"Being a father's important to me personally," Offset said. "For instance, there's a big party on Saturday, right? In Los Angeles. And my son Kody's first football game is on Sunday. There's no way I'm missing either event, so I'm going to have to make it work. It's priority to me."
The PEOPLE App is now available in the Apple App Store! Download it now for the most binge-worthy celeb content, exclusive video clips, astrology updates and more!

In a 2019 cover story for¬†Haute Living, the "Swing My Way" rapper opened up about how much he‚Äôs learned about being a parent since he welcomed his first child when he was 17.
‚ÄúThe¬†journey of fatherhood was¬†kind of tough for me at first,‚Äù Offset told the outlet. ‚ÄúI was trying to find myself. I didn‚Äôt have much direction on what it meant to be a father.‚Äù
‚ÄúI definitely made some mistakes, but I have no regrets,‚Äù he continued, adding that things were especially difficult when his children were younger and he had to spend time away from them while¬†performing across the country.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs challenging when you have a career like this and you‚Äôre constantly on the road. It makes it tough to see your kids, especially when they‚Äôre young,‚Äù Offset explained. ‚ÄúNow that I‚Äôm older, though, I‚Äôm learning my way.‚Äù

title: All About Alex Cooper, Host of the 'Call Her Daddy' Podcast
description: Alex Cooper, host of the 'Call Her Daddy' podcast on Spotify, is known for her interviews with some of Hollywood's biggest celebrities. Here's everything to know about Cooper.
content:
Here's everything to know about Alex Cooper, the podcast host who's famously interviewed stars including Miley Cyrus, Jane Fonda and Hailey Bieber
Alex Cooper is the name behind one of the most successful podcasts to date: Call Her Daddy.
Self-titled the "Founding Father," Cooper has taken the podcast in a direction that's evolved tremendously since its release in 2018. Originally synonymous with its sex-heavy topics in what was branded "female locker-room talk," her podcast now puts "a modern twist on feminism" in each episode that airs, according to marketing materials.
While Call Her Daddy covers a wide range of topics in typical podcast fashion, Cooper has become known for her tell-all interviews with Hollywood's A-listers. Guests have included Miley Cyrus, Chelsea Handler, John Mayer, Kelsea Ballerini and fake German heiress Anna Delvey.
In June 2021, Cooper and Spotify made a three-year deal worth more than $60 million in total, per Variety, which makes it the streaming platform's biggest exclusive deal for a female-led podcast ever. "I want to be the biggest podcast in the world," Cooper revealed to the Wall Street Journal.
With an annual salary of $20 million, Cooper is now the highest-paid female podcaster on Spotify ‚Äî and second only to Joe Rogan overall, the Los Angeles Times reported in June 2022. "A woman just got what in the past would've been a male contract," she told the outlet.
As for her personal life, Cooper married Hollywood producer Matt Kaplan in April 2024.
Here's everything to know about Cooper, from her days as a Division I college athlete to her globally recognized career.
Prior to Cooper's three-year Spotify deal in 2021, Barstool Sports acquired Call Her Daddy approximately one month after its first episode aired in 2018.
Since the podcast's debut, the show's structure has evolved tremendously. Among one of the major changes? Cooper now hosts solo, a duty that came after parting ways with Sofia Franklyn ‚Äî her former co-host, best friend and business partner ‚Äî in April 2020.
The podcast went dark that year, leading tabloids and fans ‚Äî deemed the "Daddy Gang" ‚Äî to speculate about a fallout between Cooper and Franklyn, especially since the two posted that they "legally can't speak out" on the behind-the-scenes talk at the time.
Details remain murky as to what exactly caused the partnership to "go up in flames," as Time put it, but it was in part due to a contract renegotiation with Barstool Sports. Ultimately, Cooper picked Call Her Daddy back up, while Franklyn started her own show a few months later.
For years, Call Her Daddy was synonymous with sex. It was known for raunchy talk and coining concepts like the "Gluck Gluck 9000" (an oral sex technique, FYI), keeping with the program's original "female locker-room talk" ethos.
Today, Cooper still exudes big-sister energy with the sex advice she distributes, but her content has evolved and expanded ‚Äî despite people telling her "they miss the old Call Her Daddy," she told the Los Angeles Times. Now, she covers a wider range of topics and caters to a broader demographic.
"It was like, 'How many times can we talk about sex?'" she told the Los Angeles Times. "I was getting a little bit bored. I need to be mentally stimulated by my content."
Since then, topics on the show have included "reclaiming your power" after experiencing trauma, sexual fluidity, self-love and debunking mental health stigmas. Most of all, she wants to expand her conversations into the realm of female empowerment.
Furthermore, Call Her Daddy has taken on an interview-heavy format, featuring conversations between Cooper and some of the biggest names in Hollywood. The Q&A style is intimate, and Cooper gets stars to be candid about headline-making topics.
For example, when Jamie Lynn Spears was a guest on the show, she hoped to put to rest the accusations that she didn't help her sister Britney throughout her conservatorship. Hailey Baldwin Bieber revealed her favorite sex position with husband Justin Bieber, while Jane Fonda opened up about the "secret life" she used to live while struggling with an eating disorder.
On April 6, 2024, Cooper and Kaplan wed in Riviera Maya, Mexico.
‚ÄúIt was everything we wanted it to be,‚Äù the podcast host told¬†Vogue. ‚ÄúIt was emotional, heartfelt, and we tailored it to exactly how we always envisioned it.‚Äù
Cooper walked down the aisle in a custom gown by designer Danielle Frankel, while Kaplan donned a custom suit by The Cloakroom.
The Hollywood producer proposed to Cooper in March 2023 at their home in Los Angeles.
"I like, blacked out," Cooper recalled of the moment her now-husband got down on one knee. "I think I said, 'yes,' at first. It was very surreal."
Their engagement came after three years of dating, during most of which Cooper kept Kaplan's identity a secret from her fans. When mentioning him on her podcast, she would refer to him as only "Mr. Sexy Zoom Man" until revealing his identity in April 2023.
Although Cooper's fanbase has primarily consisted of millennials and Gen-Z over the years, there are two people who have been loyal followers since day one: her parents.
"They have always been my number one supporters," Cooper told Today. "Even when people in my extended family would be like, 'Has she lost her mind?', my parents were like, 'No, because we know Alex and we know how we raised her and we know her talent.'"
Cooper's mom Laurie, a psychologist, has appeared on Call Her Daddy several times in the past. But while Cooper has created a name for herself as a go-to for advice, she's also gained some guidance from the person who knows her best.
"If she's talking to me about relationships, it's like, 'Do not lose yourself just to be with someone. Stay true to who you are,'" Cooper told E! News. "I think that goes through to every other aspect whether that's job, friendship, life, career."
If there's something Cooper wants to make clear, it's that her success wasn't something that she just "fell into." Having attended Boston University as a Division I soccer player while majoring in film and television, the Call Her Daddy host worked hard to land where she is now.
Cooper's publicist considers her a "one-woman operation," the Los Angeles Times reported. In addition to recording her own podcasts, she researches and edits almost entirely herself. According to Time, Spotify claims she's the most "hands-on" podcasting talent on its roster.
"There's this assumption that making a podcast is easy, but it's a lot of f‚Äîing work. I take it with great pride that my whole life revolves around it," she told the Los Angeles Times. "Every Sunday I'm working, I work seven days a week. And I love it. I would not want to do anything else."
